basics.title: echo
basics.content:
It's traditional in computer science to start with a simple "Hello World" program

In Linux we can print to the screen using the echo command. Try it out by printing "Hello World" to the screen! echo "example string"

basics.title: date
basics.content:
Lets find out through the command line what time it is and get todays date by using the
date
commanddate

basics.title: pwd
basics.content:
The core philisophy in Linux is that everything is a file, meaning that every file and folder (directory) are treated as file-like objects to allow for fast and easy flowing navigation throughout your system

The command line is where you input commands into your system and it all begins in your root directory

The directory is just another term for folder. Lets see what current directory we are in by using the command pwd (print working directory)

pwd

basics.title: ls
basics.content:
By using pwd we can see that our current directory is the root directory represented by the '/' symbol.

The root directory is the head of the filesystem, it all begins here.

To see what lives in the our current directory at any given time, we can use the ls command, which stands for "list"

ls

basics.title: cd
basics.content:
As we can see via the ouput ls gave, our content inside the current directory (which was the root directory) showed:

Documents/ Pictures/ Projects/ Videos/

Content marked with the backlash '/' are your directories (folders) which can contain other directories and folders

To see what is inside, lets go into our Documents/ directory with the cd command, which stands for "change directory".cd Example_Directory/

basics.title: cd
basics.content:
As we can see via the ouput ls gave, our content inside the current directory (which was the root directory) showed:

Documents/ Pictures/ Projects/ Videos/

Content marked with the backlash '/' are your directories (folders) which can contain other directories and folders

To see what is inside, lets go into our Documents/ directory with the cd command, which stands for "change directory".cd Example_Directory/

basics.title: cat
basics.content:
Now that we are in our Documents directory, we can see that it contains directories and files that end in .txt

To access the content in these files we can use the cat command, which stands for concatenate.

Lets try it out by seeing what is inside 'hello.txt', it could be a roaring surprise!

cat hello.txt
